feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
Particles of reported speech and inference
Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: According to Magomedova & Abdulaeva (2007: 704) also used to mark indirect questions, though the example provided looks like a regular quotative construction with the verb ‘ask’.
example_as_in_source: Ачи охьакье йекъ1егье йик1вари гьудуйе / Ачикье йекъ1егье йик1вари гьудуйе
translation_as_in_source: Она приходила просить денег взяймы. Replaced palochka with 1.
example_comment: Kind of a weird example to be honest.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: Particles “agree” with the tense of the predicate: non-aorist / aorist. See Maisak (2017).
example_as_in_source: isa-di rac’ːin-dːu en.š-la ɬe-di=ɬoʁo rela ɢobi=dːu
translation_as_in_source: Jesus asked, “Who touched me?”
example_comment: Originally from another source. Shows a particle that splits into two parts.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: Particles “agree” with the tense of the predicate: non-aorist / aorist. See Maisak (2017).
example_as_in_source: onšːi mola-rasadin.o-di b-ičːi=ɬodi ʟ’ankːala, b-ikːoɬi=ɬodi hede-b gʷal.u-la hinu.
translation_as_in_source: One day Molla-Nasreddin caught a hare and put it in a sack.
gloss_source: once Molla-Nasreddin-erg iii-catch.aor=rep hare iii-be.caus.aor=rep dist-iii sack-in inside
example_comment: Originally from another source.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: Particles “agree” with the tense of the predicate: non-aorist / aorist. See Maisak (2017).
translation_as_in_source: Отец пришел, говорится.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
example_as_in_source: Ч1акъваруди рул1идду къгамкъгухъи, гьинджелло бикъгобор сорохъи рулогъо: “Анжиди джилъибор, кьетур букъогъодду”.
translation_as_in_source: Перепел сказал синице, еще и если придет лисе скажи: “топор если есть, дерево срубить, мол”.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: Particles “agree” with the tense of the predicate: non-aorist / aorist. See Maisak (2017).
example_as_in_source: ali-l’o ruʟ-o, ho-<w>a wuɢo-b=ʁojd / ali-d di-l’o ruʟi, ži-w w-ukon=ɬoʁojd
translation_as_in_source: Tell Ali to come here. / Ali told me he ate already.
gloss_source: Ali-super.lat say-imp [prox-lat<m> m-come-imp]=quot / Ali-erg I-super.lat say.aor [self-m m-eat.aor]=quot
example_comment: Examples for both non-aorist and aorist form.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: Particles “agree” with the tense of the predicate: non-aorist / aorist. See Maisak (2017).
translation_as_in_source: There lived (= there was, there was not) one king… {beginning of a fairy-tale}
example_comment: Only non-aorist form example.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: Particles “agree” with the tense of the predicate: non-aorist / aorist. See Maisak (2017).
translation_as_in_source: A thorn stuck [into his leg].

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
translation_as_in_source: It seems to me that the rain has stopped, I do not hear the noise [anymore].
example_comment: Example without ʁo.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
example_as_in_source: to-w χʷe-r-t̄e-r-ši e‹w›di žu is q’onq’ eɬu-t’ō-r-ši.
translation_as_in_source: He swore he did not steal my book.
example_comment: Examples in Daniel (2006) show that the quotative / reportative can be placed inside a converb, or be followed with an attributive marker. It also seems to be two distinct but identical morphemes which differ in terms of distribution.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: Reported speech is marked with general subordinators, see Dum-Tragut (2009).

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
translation_as_in_source: (He) (apparently) took it.
example_comment: Not clear to what extent this marks hearsay (see translation). Example comes from the draft version of the paper and is not in the published version.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
example_as_in_source: Гьес вацасда бицана, жиз кин цӀалулев вугевали
translation_as_in_source: Он брату рассказал, как он учится.
example_comment: Non-finite main predicate.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
example_as_in_source: Гьаб хабар щибилан вачӀана эмен рокъове
translation_as_in_source: Что за раз­говоры, мол, пришел отец домой
example_comment: No speech matrix verb.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
example_as_in_source: ħami-t’a-sa ɣorƛ-e-gun rik’ː-an=ila ħamul, b-ug=ila anc’a-b=go ħama
translation_as_in_source: Down from the donkey, he counted them. Apparently there are 10 donkeys.
gloss_source: donkey.obl-spr-abl down-lat-comit count-aor=evid donkey.pl n-cop=evid ten-n=prt donkey
example_comment: From a folktale. Originally from another source.

comment: Imperfective converb of ‘say’.
example_as_in_source: xːunul-li tiladi b-arq’-ib ca-b hel-i-cːe “ma-ax-utːa!” r-ik’-ul
translation_as_in_source: His wife begged him “Do not go!”

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: Perfective converb of ‘say’.
example_as_in_source: Ramazan ʁaj b-ičː-ib dam “kumek b-irq’-an=da” haʔ-ib-le
translation_as_in_source: Ramazan promised me “I will help (you).”
gloss_source: Ramazan word n-give.pfv-pret 1sg.dat help n-do.ipfv-ptcp=1 say.pfv-pret-cvb

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
translation_as_in_source: {CI: The speaker has just seen the president arrive (no one had expected this event): - Have you heard the news? C2: The speaker has just heard that the president arrived unexpectedly but has not witnessed the event: -Have you heard the news?} The President came!
example_comment: Replaced macron with a lengthmark.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
example_as_in_source: jaš-u-di hiʟ’i il-u-qi den quča b=aχ-i-ʟi-bu-da-ʟ’u
translation_as_in_source: Daughter told mother: “I will bring the book.” (lit. Daughter said to mother, having said, I will bring the book.)

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: Particles “agree” with the tense of the predicate: simple past / non-simple past. Co-occur with -ƛ’u, but -ƛ’u can occur without these two particles.
example_as_in_source: ʕali-di hiʟ’i il-u-qi in-šː-o niša bu=š-al-at-a-wa:-ʟ’u
translation_as_in_source: Ali told (his) mother that he was collecting apricots.
example_comment: Particle wa replaces copula ida in the construction.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: Particles “agree” with the tense of the predicate: simple past / non-simple past.
example_as_in_source: di-ɬi rukː-at-a-da ʕali wu=na-ɬa:-ʟ’u ʕali wu=na-ɬaqi-ʟ’u
translation_as_in_source: It seems to me that Ali has left.
example_comment: Replaced macron with a lengthmark.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
translation_as_in_source: The crow said “Krah.”

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
translation_as_in_source: The giant wondered and got afraid.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
translation_as_in_source: “Did you feed the guest?” - he said.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
example_as_in_source: Tq’ea shi’ inaral voaghar ealar, shie propusk jalcha maara, cynna t’y-vaxa jish jolazh vaacar ealar yzh.
translation_as_in_source: 22 generals would come to get the permit without which they couldn’t go to see him (the czar), he said.
gloss_source: 20 two-nz general v.come.impf say.wp 3srfl pass j.give.cvtemp only 3s.dat at-v.go.inf possibility j.be.cvsim v.prog:neg.pst say.wp 3p

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
example_as_in_source: T’aaqqa, vaampal veaghaav joax, tur wa=’a ottadea k’al …
translation_as_in_source: A vaampal (giant) was sitting there with his sword laid out before him…
gloss_source: so then giant v.sit.nw.v quot sword dx=& stand-d.cs.cvant under

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: According to Gadžieva (2007: 140), ƛ’i appears in the “inlaut” of the word, ƛ’a in the “auslaut”, judging from examples in Magomedbekova (1971: 173) this means ƛ’i can appear between the verb root and the converb suffix -baχ, while ƛ’a appears after the verb form.; According to Magomedbekova (1971: 173) all quotative particles derive from keƛ’e ‘said’.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: According to Magomedbekova (1971: 173) all quotative particles derive from keƛ’e ‘said’.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: General tense of č’ala ‘to inform, to hear’. Similar construction of unclear status discussed in Khalilova (2009: 239), example 447.
translation_as_in_source: They say that today (they) will give (us) money.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: General indirect evidentiality marker borrowed from Azerbaijani. No quotative attested.
translation_as_in_source: The master of the house where they arrived had died.
example_comment: According to Authier (2010: 16): “non-direct evidence in the past, not necessarily remote”

Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: verb ‘say’ past
example_as_in_source: Хыных 'Мыкьа йиъи, мыкьа йиъи' хьур, некьик кирхьури
translation_as_in_source: Мальчик, жалуясь на холод, уснул (букв. Мальчик Холодно есть, холодно есть сказав, в сон упал).

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: verb ‘say’ present
example_as_in_source: Нин, нин!' рухьура, рухьура рыш некьиклаа киирхьури
translation_as_in_source: Мама, мама говоря, девочка проснулась (букв. Мама, мама говоря,  говоря, девочка из сна выпала).

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
translation_as_in_source: Мальчик говорит, что ему холодно (букв. ""Мальчик ""холодно есть"" говорит"")

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
translation_as_in_source: The colonel, it seems, is intervening.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: Verb ‘say’ present gerund.
translation_as_in_source: Он сказал, что прочтет. (досл. Он сказал, прочту, говоря.)
example_comment: Dialect of the village Gumi (Northern Tabasaran).

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference

example_comment: Dialect of the village Gumi (Northern Tabasaran).

comment: Tat uses a general complementizer ki to mark speech complements.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: Also used in hearsay constructions, see Boeder (2000: 279-280).
translation_as_in_source: In the earth, there was a gold jar, it is said.

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: From < me vtkvi 'I said'. First person form.
translation_as_in_source: How many times have I told you not to close the door (I said)!

feature: Particles of reported speech and inference
comment: Third person equivalent of metki. Is also used in first person in dialects and spoken Georgian (Ramat & Topadze 2007: 16).
translation_as_in_source: Tell him/her, to come soon. (literally: tell her/him, come soon, s/he said).
